Also <@U0XNRE25S>, to answer your question: ``` /**
   * Pin the bitmap so that it cannot be 'purged'. Only makes sense for purgeable bitmaps
   * WARNING: Use with caution. Make sure that the pinned bitmap is recycled eventually. Otherwise,
   * this will simply eat up ashmem memory and eventually lead to unfortunate crashes.
   * We *may* eventually provide an unpin method - but we don't yet have a compelling use case for
   * that.
   * @param bitmap the purgeable bitmap to pin
   */```
<https://github.com/facebook/fresco/blob/89477f77af3b6954f57dc39b8c572b4b8eb4e84a/imagepipeline/src/main/java/com/facebook/imagepipeline/nativecode/Bitmaps.java>

oh man
writing a small wrapper around Picasso is fine imo
why be a team player when you could just be a lone wolf?
if it allows you to switch to another image lib easier in the future
yeah that's true, i guess that benefit was masked by the fact they named it PicassoLoader
ImageLoader would have made it sound like more of a generic interface
universal image loader
i use this from long time never have a single issue...
"Took over the project that has been using Fresco heavily, and the current sprint has no room to switch just yet” Tech Debt Walking
Exactly!
Nevermind, looks like we may switch over to glide!

This is the current argument to use Fresco….
>Images aren't stored in the Java heap, but in the ashmem heap. Intermediate byte buffers are also stored in the native heap. This leaves a lot more memory available for applications to use. It reduces the risk of OutOfMemoryErrors. It also reduces the amount of garbage collection apps have to do, leading to better performance.

Thoughts?
that’s the argument against fresco.
Ashmem is supposed to be used for sharing memory between processes, not to save images.
Also, they don’t provide a method to unpin it from memory.
Nowadays, phones have enough memory that OOM is a rare thing, even in image heavy apps (we use Glide, we load tooons of images, all good).
Google is giving a talk on using Glide at this year’s IO
so safe to say that they support it
Glide is awesome.
Not so awesome :simple_smile:

Why not?
I haven’t had any issues with it.
We had some problems when trying to load the same image into views with different sizes and using different transformations/transcoders.
really? What was going on?
Let’s say you have to `ImageView`s. One is 48x48 and the other one is 56x56. You image is 64x64. Glide fetches this image twice and store two resized copies of it in the heap.
oh yep, it doesn’t keep the original image in cache
oh no wait, glide puts both in cache, picasso only caches one
But you can avoid resizing it and just set a proper scale type. Unfortunately placeholders do not work well in this case.
anyways, couldn’t you just set the cache strategy to keep the original only?
Glide stores the original image in cache if you specify a corresponding caching flag.
If you keep only the original one then Glide will resize it every time you’re trying to load it.
that seems semi-reasonable as a default though, since presumably you’d be loading the image into those same dimensions again
so it would cache the transformed image?
And we cared more about polluting heap rather than growing the disk cache.
default is cache all versions
So in the example I mentioned above you will end up with two resized images in memory instead of one image of the original size.
that seems reasonable to me as a default strategy though
Glide’s default strategy is to resize everything which doesn’t always work well.
Yep, and for me too.
But when you want it to work the other way you face some tough problems.
oh, if you’re saying it’s not flexible to change that strategy then I see your point
Finally we had about 20+ support classes to make it work and some of these classes used Glide package-private stuff.
yikes
Yes, that’s exactly what I’m saying :simple_smile:
how long ago was this? recent?
It was 3.6.x I think. Just a half of a year ago.
But at least after we implemented all this stuff Glide worked fine. Because Fresco doesn’t :disappointed:
Fresco’s default cache configuration is crap.
Some buffer sizes are just hardcoded.

text: hi guys, my app currently using fragments massively
and i found if so hard to deal with all the fragment's lifecycle stuffs
the pain is even bigger since i use nested fragments in some places of the app
recently i read some articles about eliminating all the fragments and just use views instead
i found it reasonable, anyone try it out?
i mean, a fragment-free architecture
We started removing fragments from our app and yes it's possible
sounds promising
do you use any supporting library to deal with the navigating, backstack handling, etc.
i read about the mortar and flow library, but i not sure should i use them
since the learning curve is steep and we have to stick to it all the way
might also want to check this out <https://github.com/lyft/scoop>
